titleStmt.title: Despatch from William Walker to the Commander of the Saratoga, December 18, 1861

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.title: Despatch from William Walker to the Commander of the Saratoga, December 18, 1861
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

div1.opener:
Gaboon Dec.18.1861.
To the Commander of the Saratoga
Gabon Dec.18.1881
Sir,
div1.p: I have but a moment to write by a French man of war, "Decheiche," going South to inform you of the death of Cap. R.E. Lawlin of Camma. The French Commodore, Baron Didelot, has kindly offered to order the vessel which carries this letter, to stop and communicate with the factory and people. But it would detain her one or two days and we have no vessel to go and get the cargo. So I have not thought it worth while to trouble him. I presume though when we get ready to settle the business, he will be willing to render any needed assistance.

It is a sad case that Capt. Lawlin should die there alone. Can you not make it in your way to go there immediately and protect the property ? I received a letter from his merchants by last mail, & they spoke of the possibilty of this same event. I shall engage at the earliest moment a vessel to go and take off the goods, and bring them to Gaboon. But we fear diffculty with the natives. I shall write you via Fernando Po.

closer.salute:
In the mean time,
I remain
Very Tuly Yours
closer.signed:
Wm. Walker
Acting U.S. Vice Commercial Agent.
